FuncDef:
The dual-active detection source ipv6 command specifies the IPv6 address bound to a DFS group.
The undo dual-active detection source ipv6 command cancels the configuration. The dual-active detection source ipv6 command specifies the IPv6 address bound to a DFS group. The undo dual-active detection source ipv6 command cancels the configuration. By default, no IPv6 address is bound to a DFS group. This command is supported only on the CE6863H, CE6863H-K, CE6860-SAN, CE6866K, CE6866, CE6860-HAM, CE6855-48XS8CQ, CE6885-SAN, CE8850-SAN, CE8855, CE8851-32CQ4BQ, CE8851K, CE8851-32CQ8DQ-P, CE8850-HAM, CE6881H, CE6881H-K, CE6820H, CE6820H-K, CE6820S, CE6885, CE6885-T, CE6885-LL (standard forwarding mode) and CE6863E-48S8CQ.
CLIs: dual-active detection source ipv6 <ipv6-address1> [ peer <ipv6-address2> [ udp-port <portnum> ] ] [ timeout <seconds> ]
undo dual-active detection source ipv6 <ipv6-address1> [ [ peer <ipv6-address2> [ udp-port <portnum> ] ] [ timeout <seconds> ] ]

ParaDef.Info:
Specifies the peer device's IPv6 address bound to a DFS group.
The value is a 32-digit hexadecimal number, in the format of X:X:X:X:X:X:X:X.

Specifies the UDP port number bound to a DFS group.
The value is an integer that ranges from 1025 to 2048. The default value is the smallest idle port number between 1025 and 2048.

Specifies the timeout duration.
The value is an integer ranging from 3 to 60, in seconds. The default value is 45.

Specifies the IPv6 address bound to a DFS group.
The value is a 32-bit hexadecimal string in format X:X:X:X:X:X:X:X.

Examples: [*HUAWEI-dfs-group-1] dual-active detection source ipv6 2001:db8:1::1 peer 2001:db8:1::2 udp-port 2048 timeout 30
ExtraInfo:
When a CE is dual-homed to two PEs on an Ethernet, VXLAN, or IP network, to enable PEs to exchange heartbeat packets, DFS groups need to be bound to IP addresses of Layer 3 interfaces connecting the two PEs. If the IP network uses IPv6 addresses, a DFS group needs to be bound to an IPv6 address. If the CE connects to a VPN, you must specify the VPN instance bound to a DFS group.
Assume that the heartbeat IP address and UDP port number of the peer device are specified when the heartbeat IP address bound to a DFS group is configured. When the configuration takes effect, the two M-LAG devices immediately start to send and receive heartbeat packets and negotiate the HB DFS master/backup status. In scenarios where enhanced DAD for secondary faults is enabled, if faults on the original DFS master device are rectified and the peer-link fault persists, the corresponding interfaces on the backup device are triggered to enter the Error-Down state based on the HB DFS master/backup status. This mechanism prevents abnormal traffic forwarding in the scenario where two master devices exist and improves device reliability.
